memberdef.type: std::function< csl::Expr( QuantumField const &, QuantumField const &, csl::Tensor &, bool)>
memberdef.definition: using mty::QuantumFieldParent::Propagator_func = std::function<csl::Expr( QuantumField const &, QuantumField const &, csl::Tensor &, bool)>
memberdef.name: Propagator_func

briefdescription.para: Type definition. A Propagator_func is a function called to get the propagator result of the contraction of two fields.

detaileddescription.para: The function is contained in a std::function. Such an object may be instantiated with a c++ lambda function or a standard function defined normally. The function or lambda must take four arguments. The two fields contracted (QuantumField), the momentum integrated (csl::Tensor), and a boolean telling if one of the two fields is external. It must return an expression (csl::Expr) that is the propagator between the two fields for which the factor $\frac{d^4p}{(2\pi)^4}$ has been removed. Implementations assure that if the field is complex, the conjugated field is always the second argument. If one of the fields is external, the propagator should be adapted. For example, the propagator of two scalar fields is \[ \frac{ie^{-ipX}}{p^2-m^2}, \] whereas if one of the fields is external, the projection on the equations of motion $ \partial _\mu\partial ^\mu + m^2 $ gives simply \[ -ie^{-ipX}. \] The Propagator_func must provide the entire expression of the propagator but the integral $ \int \frac{d^4p}{(2\pi)^4} $ that is automatically added. In quantumFieldTheory.h / quantumFieldTheory.cpp all built-in propagators are written in the form of standard c++ functions. Propagators for any particle may be changed by the user. See mty::AddCustomPropagator().

briefdescription.para: True if the field is bosonic.
True if the field is real (real scalars, gauge bosons , majorana fermions).

detaileddescription.para:
By default, all particles are complex except VectorBoson fields that are set real. This value has an impact in wick contractions.
isSelfConjugate(), setSelfConjugate().

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is integrated out in the theory. If true, the propagator is modified assuming $ M \gg p $.
Tells if the field is physical. If true, it may appear in external states. Otherwise it is forbidden.
Tells if the field is enabled in diagrams. If no, it is fully discarded in computations.
Mass of the particle. Appears in the propagator.
Width of the particle. Appears in the propagator.
Particle type in graphical diagrams (straight line, arrow, vector, gluon ...).
Pointer to the space-time group. For know it is the Lorentz group, $ D_2 $ algebra.
Spin representation in stGroup. To have a number corresponding to the spin, see getSpinDimension().
Pointer to the gauge the particle is a representation of.
Representation of the field in the gauge gauge.
Boolean making sure that polarization sum (see PolarizationField) is initialized only onde.
Position of the first gauge index, after flavor indices.
Position of the first space index, after flavor and gauge indices.
Pointer to the flavor the particle is a representation of.
Representation of the field in the flavor flavor.
Contains all propagators for the field with other.

detaileddescription.para: Maps another field to a Propagator_func. For example, a vector boson has two propagators. One with itself, see mty::VectorPropagator in quantumFieldTheory.h, one with its field strength, see mty::FieldStrengthPropagator in quantumFieldTheory.h. Propagators may be modified through the function mty::AddCustomPropagator.

briefdescription.para: Default constructor.
Copy constructor.
Constructor with 3 parameters.

detaileddescription.para:
The gauge representation, not given here, is initialized to the trivial representation. The flavor is null and no flavor representation is created. The particle is by default complex.
t_name
Name of the field.
t_spin
Integer equal to twice the spin of the particle.
t_gauge
Pointer to the gauge of the model.

briefdescription.para: Constructor with 3 parameters.

detaileddescription.para:
The gauge reprensentation, is initialized to irrep. The flavor is null and no flavor representation is created. The particle is by default complex.
t_name
Name of the field.
t_spin
Integer equal to twice the spin of the particle.
irrep
Gauge representation of the field.

detaileddescription.para:
The gauge representation, not given here, is initialized to the trivial representation. The flavor is null and no flavor representation is created.

Name of the field.
t_spin

t_gauge
Pointer to the gauge of the model.
t_isSelfConjugate
Boolean that must be true for real fields, false otherwise.

detaileddescription.para:
The gauge reprensentation, is initialized to irrep. The flavor representation is initialized to flavorRep. The particle is by default complex.
t_name
Name of the field.
t_spin
Integer equal to twice the spin of the particle.

briefdescription.para: Builds a new particle identical to another, with a different name.
Returns the drawing type of the particle.

simplesect.para: The drawing type of the particle.

briefdescription.para: Sets the drawing type of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
The drawing type is how the particle will be drawn on diagrams.
type
Type of line for the particle in diagrams.
drawType, getDrawType().

briefdescription.para: Pure virtual function. Generates a partical similar to the current object, changing only the name.

parameterdescription.para: Name of the new particle, identical to the current object.

briefdescription.para: Returns the chirality of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
A DiracFermion or boson will return Chirality::None. WeylFermion will return either Chirality::Left or Chirality::Right.
The chirality of the particle.

briefdescription.para: Pure virtual function. Returns the energy dimension of the field.

simplesect.para: An expression (numerical) equal to the dimension of the field.

briefdescription.para: Pure virtual function. Returns the number of degrees of freedom in the particle. It does not count gauge and flavor multiplicity. The result depends on the type of the particle and if it is complex.

simplesect.para: An integer, number of degrees of freedom of the particle.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field has a special contraction property with other.

parameterdescription.para: Field with which there may be a contraction.

simplesect.para: True if there is a contraction property.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is chiral.

simplesect.para: True if the field is a WeylFermion.

briefdescription.para: For a WeylFermion embedded in a DiracFermion, returns the other part of the DiracFermion.

simplesect.para: The right WeylFermion for a left WeylFermion embedded in a DiracFermion.
The left WeylFermion for a right WeylFermion embedded in a DiracFermion.

briefdescription.para: For a DiracFermion, returns the chiral WeylFermion it contains of chirality chirality if it has one.

parameterdescription.para: Chirality of the WeylFermion we want to get.

simplesect.para: The WeylFermion of chirality chirality if there is one embedded in the DiracFermion.

briefdescription.para: For a WeylFermion embedded in a DiracFermion, returns the dirac fermion.

simplesect.para: A the DiracFermion embedding the current WeylFermion.

briefdescription.para: For a vector boson in a non abelian gauged group, returns the associated Goldstone boson.

simplesect.para: The Goldstone associated with the vector if there is one.

memberdef.argsstring: (QuantumField const &self, QuantumField const &other, csl::Tensor &P, bool external) const
memberdef.name: getPropagator

briefdescription.para: Returns the expression of the propagator between two fields.

parameterdescription.para: True if one of the two fields is an external leg.

simplesect.para: The expression of the propagator without the integral term $ \int \frac{d^4p}{(2\pi)^4} $.

memberdef.argsstring: (QuantumField const &other, QuantumField const &self, csl::Tensor &P, bool external) const
memberdef.name: getInvPropagator

briefdescription.para: Returns the expression of the propagator between two fields.

detaileddescription.para:
Propagator_func.
This function is called when the left field is complex conjugated. When it is the case, in order to ensure that the conjugate is on the right, the order is reverted.
other
Left field of the propagator.
self
Right field of the propagator.
P
Momentum integrated in the propagator.
external
True if one of the two fields is an external leg.
The expression of the propagator without the integral term $ \int \frac{d^4p}{(2\pi)^4} $.

briefdescription.para: Returns the kinetic term in the Lagrangian for the field.

detaileddescription.para:
This function is overriden in derived classes. Each particle has a specific form for its kinetic term, including covariant derivatives and mass term. An example of kinetic term for a complex scalar field is \[ \mathcal{L}\ni (D_\mu \phi)^\dagger D^\mu\phi - m_\phi^2\phi ^\dagger \phi, \] where $ D_\mu $ stands for the covariant derivative of the field including interactions with gauge vector fields.
mty::gauge::covariantDerivative().
X
Space-time point for the kinetic term.
The mathematical expression in the Lagrangian for the field.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the particle is a gauge boson.

simplesect.para: True if the particle is a gauge boson (created by a GaugedGroup).

briefdescription.para: For a GaugeBoson, returns the expression of $ \xi $ in the current gauge.

simplesect.para: $ \xi $ in the current gauge of the field if it is a gauge boson.

briefdescription.para: For a ghost or goldstone boson, returns the GaugeBoson associated with it.

simplesect.para: The GaugeBoson associated with the Golstone or Ghost.

briefdescription.para: For a GaugeBoson, returns the associated Golstone boson of there is one.

simplesect.para: The GoldstoneBoson associated to the GaugeBoson is it exists.

briefdescription.para: For a GoldstoneBoson, returns the associated Golstone boson of there is one.

simplesect.para: The GoldstoneBoson associated to the GoldstoneBoson is it exists.

briefdescription.para: For a GaugeBoson, sets the associated GoldstoneBoson.

detaileddescription.para:
After the call of this function, the link os created and the calling getGoldstoneBoson() for the gauge boson or getVectorBoson() for the golstone will indeed yield the right particles. The golstone boson must have the exact same representation as the gauge boson except the spin. This function is called automatically when creating a golstone boson from a gauge boson through mty::golstoneboson_s(), or through Model::promoteToGoldstone().
mty::golstoneboson_s, Model::promoteToGoldstone(), GoldstoneBoson.
goldstone
Particle that takes the place of a golstone boson for the curent gauge boson.

briefdescription.para: For a GaugeBoson, sets the associated GhostBoson.

detaileddescription.para:
After the call of this function, the link os created and the calling getGhostBoson() for the gauge boson or getVectorBoson() for the ghost will indeed yield the right particles. The ghost boson must have the exact same representation as the gauge boson except the spin. This function is called automatically when creating a ghost boson from a gauge boson through mty::ghostboson_s().
mty::ghostboson_s, GhostBoson.
ghost
Particle that takes the place of a ghost boson for the curent gauge boson.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the particle has a FieldStrength.

detaileddescription.para:
A FieldStrength is defined automatically for VectorBoson fields, gauge bosons or not. It is defined as \[ F^I_{\mu
u} \equiv \partial _\mu A^I_
u - \partial _
u A^I_\mu, \] with $ A^A_\mu $ a vector boson with a generic index $ I $ representing all flavor and gauge structures. If the field strength is defined, the kinetic term is expressed as $ - rac{1}{4}F^I_{\mu
u} F^{I\mu
u} $ and contractions like $ \langle A^I_\mu F^J_{
uho} angle $ or $ \langle F^I_{\mu
u}F^J_{ho\sigma}angle $ are defined by built-in propagators.
VectorBoson, FieldStrength, Propagator_func, quantumFieldTheory.h.
True if the particle (should be a VectorBoson) has a FieldStrength defined.
False else.

briefdescription.para: For a VectorBoson, returns the associated FieldStrength if it exists.

simplesect.para: The FieldStrength of the the VectorBoson if it exists.

briefdescription.para: For a VectorBoson, sets the associated FieldStrength.

detaileddescription.para:
The fieldStrength must of course be consitent with the actual field.
hasFieldStrength(), FieldStrength, VectorBoson.
The FieldStrength of the the VectorBoson if it exists.
nullptr otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field may be contracted with another in Wick contrations.

parameterdescription.para: Other field to test the contraction.

simplesect.para: True if a propagator exists between the two fields.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is bosonic.

simplesect.para: True if the field is bosonic.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is fermionic.

simplesect.para: True if the field is fermionic.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is a grassman field.

simplesect.para: True if the field if fermionic or is a ghost.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is self-conjugate (real).

detaileddescription.para:
By default, all fields except vector bosons are complex. If the field is self-conjugate, it may contract with itself (not conjugated) in wick contractions.
True if the field is real.
False if the field is complex.
selfConjugate, setSelfConjugate().

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is physical, i.e. may appear in external legs.

detaileddescription.para:
If the field is not physical, it will be forbidden in external legs. In particular, the function setExternal() will yield an error. For example, ghosts and goldstone bosons are not physical.
physical, isExternal(), setExternal(), setPhysical(), Insertion.
True if the field is physical.
False else.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is enabled in diagrams.

detaileddescription.para:
If it is not enables, each interaction containing the particle will be discarded in computations.
True if the field may appear in diagrams.
False else.
enabledInDiagrams, setEnabledInDiagrams(), Expander::Options.

briefdescription.para: Tells if the field is integrated out.

detaileddescription.para:
If true, the only thing that changes is that the propagator is replaced by an effective interaction assuming $M\gg p$. For example in the case of a massive vector boson, the standard propagator of a VectorBoson of mass $ M $ is \[ -ie^{-ipX}\frac{g_{\mu\nu} - (1-\xi)\frac{p_\mu p_\nu}{p^2-\xi M^2}} {p^2-M^2}, \] whereas its integrated propagator becomes \[ ie^{-ipX}\frac{g_{\mu\nu}}{M^2}. \] This is possible for any field (fermionic, scalar or vector).
True if the field is integrated out.
False otherwise.
integratedOut, integrateOut(), Propagator_func, quantumFieldTheory.h, EffModel, Wilson.

briefdescription.para: Returns twice the spin of the particle in an integer.

detaileddescription.para:
For simplicity, this function returns a simple integer. Half spins being not represented, the spin is multiplied by 2 before being returned. Spins of scalars, fermions and vectors are then 0, 1, 2.
Twice the spin of the particle.
spin.

briefdescription.para: Returns the expression of the mass of the particle.
Returns the expression of the witdh of the particle.
Returns the lorentz representation of the field.

simplesect.para: The spin representation of the field.

briefdescription.para: Returns a pointer to the gauge the field is a representation of.
Returns the gauge representation containing all individual group representations of the field in the gauge.

simplesect.para: The gauge representation of the field.

briefdescription.para: Returns the representation of the field in a particle group.

detaileddescription.para:
If the group is not found, an error is raised. This function works also for flavor representations.
group
Pointer to the group from which we want the representation of the field.
The representation of the field in group.
irrep, getFlavorIrrep(), getGaugeIrrep().

briefdescription.para: Returns the flavor representation containing all individual group representations of the field in the flavor.

simplesect.para: The flavor representation of the field.

briefdescription.para: Returns the representation of the field in a particle flavor group.

detaileddescription.para:
If the flavor group is not found, an error is raised.
group
Pointer to the flavor group from which we want the representation of the field.
The representation of the field in group.
flavorRep, getFlavorIrrep(), getGaugeIrrep().

briefdescription.para: Returns a set of free space indices corresponding to the field.

detaileddescription.para:
This function in general will return zero or one index. Scalar fields have no space-time index, spin 1/2 and 1 have 1. However, in order to potentially extend this function to higher spins with more space-time indices, this function returns a std::vector.
New indices generated corresponding to the space-time indices of the field.
getGaugeIndex(), getFlavorIndex(), getFullSetOfIndices().

briefdescription.para: Returns a set of gauge indices corresponding to the field.

simplesect.para: A set of new indices generated in the gauge representation spaces of the field.

briefdescription.para: Returns a set of flavor indices corresponding to the field.

simplesect.para: A set of new indices generated in the flavor representation spaces of the field.

briefdescription.para: Returns a full set of indices for the field including flavor , gauge, and space-time indices.

detaileddescription.para:
This set is composed of independent and free indices and may be used directly to generate a QuantumField. The indices are first flavor indices, then gauge indices and finally space-time indices.
A full set of new indices generated for the field.
getSpaceIndex(), getFlavorIndex(), getGaugeIndex().

briefdescription.para: Returns an instance of the quantum field as an expression.

detaileddescription.para:
This function generates a set of indices through getFullSetOfIndices(), and uses a space-time point by default or given by the user. It returns an instance of the field like $ A^{\mu A}(X) $ calling operator().
point
Sapce-time point at which the field is evaluated (optional).
An expression of the field instance with free and independent indices.
getFullSetOfIndices(), operator()().

briefdescription.para: Sets the integrated out property of the field.

detaileddescription.para:
If true, the propagator of the particle is modified, assuming $ M^2\gg p^2 $. If false, the propagator is reset to its default.
(de-)Integrating out a particle, all non default propagators defined through AddCustomPropagator() will be automatically suppressed. There are indeed in general ill-defined in this case.
value
Boolean, must be true to integrate out the particle, false else (default = true).
integrateOut, isIntegratedOut(), AddCustomPropagator(), Propagator_func, quantumFieldTheory.h.

briefdescription.para: Sets the mass of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
The mass created for the particle is a csl::Constant name t_mass. If the field is added to a Model through Model::addField() later on, the corresponding mass term is added automatically to the Lagrangian.
t_mass
Name of the constant mass.
mass, getMass().

briefdescription.para: Sets the mass of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
The mass created for the particle is a csl::Constant name t_mass with a numerical value of value. If the field is added to a Model through Model::addField() later on, the corresponding mass term is added automatically to the Lagrangian.
t_mass
Name of the constant mass.
value
Value of the mass (should be expressed in GeV).
mass, getMass().

briefdescription.para: Sets the mass of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
The expression of the mass given by the user may be anything, the only requirements is that it must be scalar (without free index). If the field is added to a Model through Model::addField() later on, the corresponding mass term is added automatically to the Lagrangian.
t_mass
Expression of the new mass for the particle.
mass, getMass().

briefdescription.para: Sets the width of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
The expression of the width given by the user may be anything, the only requirements is that it must be scalar (without free index).
t_mass
Expression of the new width for the particle.
width, getWidth().

briefdescription.para: Sets the complex conjugation property of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
If t_selfConjugate is true, the particle becomes real. Otherwise it becomes complex and $ \Phi ^*\neq \bar{\Phi} $.
t_selfConjugate
Boolean telling if the field must be real.
selfConjugate, isSelfConjugate().

briefdescription.para: Sets the physical property of the particle.

detaileddescription.para:
If t_physical is true, the field is physical and may appear as external legs of diagrams (insertions). Else, the field becomes forbidden in diagrams and setting them external will raise an error.
t_physical
Boolean telling if the field is physical (may appear in external legs).
physical, isPhysical(), setExternal().

briefdescription.para: Enables or disables the particle in diagrams.

detaileddescription.para:
If t_enabled is false, the field may not appear in any computation and will be automatically discarded. This may be useful in some cases for which we know that the contribution of one or several particles is negligible, and that computing diagrams containing them is irrelevant.
t_enabled
Boolean telling if the field may appear in diagrams.
enabledInDiagrams, isEnabledInDiagrams().

briefdescription.para: Ajusts the flavor representation of the field to a new flavor group.

detaileddescription.para:
When breaking flavor symmetry, we may sometimes be interested in breaking only partially the symmetry. For example, we may break a 3 flavor-symmetry in one light particle and a 2-flavor symmetry. This function allows to keep a flavor representation but in a different group (here for example $ SU(3) $ to $ SU(2) $).
t_flavor
New Flavor of the particle.
flavorRep, getFlavorIrrep().

briefdescription.para: Sets the representation of the field for a given group.

detaileddescription.para:
The Irrep given as parameter is an already built representation. This function is called during gauge symmetry breaking, when representation are broken. Changing the representation, the indices of the tensor change and may disappear if the new representation is trivial, or appear if the new representation is not while the old one is.
group
Group for which the field representation is changed.
newRep
New representation of the field in group.
irrep, getGroupIrrep(), getGaugeIrrep().

briefdescription.para: Sets the representation of the field for a given group.

detaileddescription.para:
The Irrep given as parameter is in the form of a std::vector of integers. These integer are the dinkin labels of the representation. This function is called during gauge symmetry breaking, when representation are broken. Changing the representation, the indices of the tensor change and may disappear if the new representation is trivial, or appear if the new representation is not while the old one is.
group
Group for which the field representation is changed.
highestWeight
Dinkin labels of the highest weight for the wanted representation.
irrep, getGroupIrrep(), getGaugeIrrep(), SemiSimpleAlgebra, SemiSimpleAlgebra::highestWeightRep(), setFlavorRep().

briefdescription.para: Sets the representation of the field for a given flavor group.

detaileddescription.para:
The Irrep given as parameter is an already built representation. This function is called during flavor symmetry breaking, when representation are broken. Changing the representation, the indices of the tensor change and may disappear if the new representation is trivial, or appear if the new representation is not while the old one is.
group
Flavor group for which the field representation is changed.
newRep
New representation of the field in group.
flavor, getFlavorIrrep(), setGroupRep().

briefdescription.para: Sets broken parts (from gauge of flavor symmetry full breaking) containing the new particles.

detaileddescription.para:
This function should not be called directly by the user in general. It overrides a csl function that allows to break a tensor into several parts. In this case the space is fully broken (no subspace left).
broken
Space that is broken in several parts.
brokenParts
New particles arising from the symmmetry breaking.

memberdef.argsstring: (const csl::Space *broken, const std::vector< const csl::Space * > &newSpace, const std::vector< size_t > &pieces) const override
memberdef.name: breakSpace

briefdescription.para: Returns the set of new tensors after breaking the particle in parts.

parameterdescription.para: Space (gauge or flavor) that is broken.
New (non trivial) vector spaces after the symmetry breaking.
Dimensions of new spaces. The sum must be equal to the dimension of broken.

simplesect.para: The set of tensors arising after the symmetry breaking.

briefdescription.para: Assignment operator (c++ default).

simplesect.para: A reference to the current object.

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the field as a symbolic expression.

detaileddescription.para:
This functions takes no csl::Index. The field is then for sure a ScalarBoson in a trivial Gauge representation. Example: $\phi(X)$.
t_point
Space_time point of the scalar field.
An expression, instance of the field.
QuantumField.

detaileddescription.para:
This functions takes one csl::Index. This may be for example a field like $ A^\mu(X) $.
index
Unique index of the field.
t_point
Space-time point of the field.
An expression, instance of the field.
QuantumField.

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the QuantumField as a symbolic expression.

parameterdescription.para: Indices of the field, as integers.

simplesect.para: An expression, instance of the field.

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the field as a symbolic expression.

detaileddescription.para:
This function takes multiple indices (may be only one) in a std::vector. This may correspond to a field like $ A^{\mu I}(X) $ .
indices
Indices of the field.
t_point
Space-time point of the field.
An expression, instance of the field.
QuantumField.

memberdef.argsstring: (csl::Index polarization, std::vector< int > const &indices, const csl::Tensor &t_point)
memberdef.name: operator()

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the PolarizationField as a symbolic expression.

parameterdescription.para: Indices of the field, as integers.

simplesect.para: An expression, instance of the field.

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the field as a symbolic expression.

detaileddescription.para:
This functions takes no csl::Index. The field is then for sure a ScalarBoson in a trivial Gauge representation. Example: $\phi(X)$. The space_time point is taken as default: see defaultSpaceTimePoint.
t_point
Space_time point of the scalar field.
An expression, instance of the field.
QuantumField.

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the field as a symbolic expression.

detaileddescription.para:
This functions takes one csl::Index. This may be for example a field like $ A^\mu(X) $. The space_time point is taken as default: see defaultSpaceTimePoint.
index
Unique index of the field.
An expression, instance of the field.
QuantumField.

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the field as a symbolic expression.

detaileddescription.para:
This function takes multiple indices (may be only one) in a std::vector. This may correspond to a field like $ A^{\mu I}(X) $ . The space_time point is taken as default: see defaultSpaceTimePoint.
indices
Indices of the field.
An expression, instance of the field.
QuantumField.

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the polarization field as a symbolic expression.

memberdef.argsstring: (csl::Index polarization, std::vector< csl::Index > indices, const csl::Tensor &momentum)

briefdescription.para: Generates an instance of the polarization field as a symbolic expression.

memberdef.argsstring: (mty::FlavorGroup *brokenFlavor, std::vector< mty::FlavorGroup * > const &subGroups, std::vector< std::string > const &names)
memberdef.name: breakParticle

briefdescription.para: Overload of operator<< for QuantumFieldParent.
Changes the propagator of a particle with another.

detaileddescription.para:
The propagator should of course be consistent, but may be as exotic as possible. See Propagator_func to know the exact structure of what must be given. This function may be useful for example to define the propagator between a left-handed and a right-handed fermion (different particles), or between a vector boson and its field strength...
field
Left field in the propagator.
field
Right field in the propagator.
propagator
New propagator.
In the case of a non symmetric propagator, the user should take into account that in its custom function, the left field will not always be the first argument. The only thing that is ensured is that if there is a complex conjugated field, it will be the second argument.
QuantumFieldParent::propagator, Propagator_func, quantumFieldTheory.h.

briefdescription.para: Changes the propagator of a particle with itself.

detaileddescription.para:
The propagator should of course be consistent, but may be as exotic as possible. See Propagator_func to know the exact structure of what must be given.
field
Field whose propagator is modified.
propagator
New propagator.
QuantumFieldParent::propagator, Propagator_func, quantumFieldTheory.h.

briefdescription.para: Initializes default propagators for the particle. This function is called automatically in the constructor of derived classes.
Initializes firstGaugeIndex and firstSpaceIndex. Automatically called by the constructor.
Initializes the polarization sum for PolarizationField arising in amplitudes.
Changes the propagator of a particle with another.

detaileddescription.para:
This function is not callable by the user. It is called instead by AddCustomPropagator() to avoid multiple definitions of propagators.
field
Other field in the propagator.
propagator
New propagator.
propagator, AddCustomPropagator().

briefdescription.para: Base class for parents of QuantumField objects.

detaileddescription.para:
A number of features are implemented in this class. Management of the mass, the width etc. Features specific to each type of field (bosonic, fermionic, ghost ...) are implemented in derived classes. QuantumFieldParent is the abstract (and unique) representation of a particle. As for csl::TensorParent or csl::TensorFieldParent, it will not appear in expressions. It contains all intrinsic features of a particle. For example in an equation, $ A $ would be the abstract photon, the QuantumFieldParent whereas $ A^{\mu A}(X) $ would be the actual field, with specific information (indices, conjugated or not, space-time point ...). This field is then a QuantumField object. The QuantumFieldParent is there to generate QuantumField when giving it indices and (optionnaly) a point $ X $. See operator(). The QuantumField keeps a pointer to its parent in order to have access to all abstract properties.
QuantumFieldParent must not be created statically. The Particle object must be created instead, a std::shared_ptr<QuantumFieldParent>.
QuantumFieldParent may not be built directly (pure abstract class). Instead, one must create a specialization. See ScalarBoson, VectorBoson, GaugeBoson, WeylFermion, DiracFermion, GoldstoneBoson, or GhostBoson.
